data.text: Contents
Introduction

Kidneys clean the blood by maintaining clearance, this is the passage of blood though millions of tiny filtering units called nephrons to create what will eventually become urine. Acute kidney injury (AKI) is the clinical syndrome caused by the abrupt loss of this function.

The term acute kidney injury replaces all previous terminology such as acute renal failure or acute renal impairment. The AKI checklist (appendix 1) is required to be used in ALL patients with AKI in the trust and is to be utilised by ALL healthcare workers. The AKI pathway is shown in (appendix 2) to guide medical management of patients.
Definition
Acute kidney injury currently defined by the rise in serum creatinine or a fall in urine output as follows:

table_items.text: 1.5 to 1.9 X baseline OR ≥ 26.5 µmol/L increase
3 X baseline OR ≥ 353.6 µmol/L increase OR Requiring RRT

data.text: Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Give guidance on patients in non-specialist areas such as A+E, acute admissions unit and adult general and medical/surgical wards
Give brief advice for AKI in the community which is in line with the Royal College of General Practice guidance.
Out of scope
Hyperkalaemia in acute kidney injury is not covered in this guideline. Please refer to the Trust hyperkalaemia guidelines. Guideline on management of Hyperkalaemia
This guideline applies to the management of acute kidney injury in adult patients only i.e. exclude paediatric AKI
This guidance is for management of AKI in hospitals. For management of AKI in primary care please refer to RCGP guidance.
Definitions

table_items.text: Renal Replacement Therapy (RRT) is therapy that replaces the normal blood filtering function of the kidneys.

An abnormal collection between two epithelialized surfaces that usually involves the gut and another hollow organ, such as the bladder, vagina, urethra or other regions of the GI tract. These can contribute to significant fluid loss.
Novel Oral Anticoagulants (NOAC) includes any of the newer anticoagulant drugs which are not vitamin K antagonists.
A syndrome resulting from the compression or obstruction of the urethra, most commonly due to hyperplasia of the prostate.
Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies. An ENA panel test is used to help diagnose a multitude of autoimmune disorders like SLE and Sjogrens.
Haemolytic Uraemic Syndrome / Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
Screening test to measure major blood proteins by separating them into five distinct fractions.
A monoclonal globulin protein or immunoglobulin light chain found in urine. Detection may be suggestive of Multiple myeloma or Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia
A form of alternative medicine that is the traditional system of medicine in India
A procedure in which a flank incision is made so that a catheter can be inserted into the renal pelvis to drain the kidney, often done to relieve obstruction.

A way to clean the blood typically done in the setting of intensive care in which there is convective transport of the solute through filtration across the membrane. This is different to dialysis where diffusion in the predominant method to clean the blood.
An exaggerated muscle tremor characterised by involuntary jerking of the hand in flexion and extension.
An estimate of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) derived from serum creatinine, age, sex and race. It gives an estimate of renal function.
Inflammation of the uveal tract: The iris, ciliary body and choroid of the eye.
An infection of the renal collecting system with collection of pus in the renal pelvis

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Individual responsibilities
Harm prevention committee: Ensure appropriate management of AKI is undertaken to prevent further harm
Renal directorate:
Ensure governance structure and systems in place for monitoring and reporting AKI, and managing severe AKI needing direct care under the renal service
Individual responsibilities
Medical Directors: responsible for ensuring that all consultants aware of and comply with this policy.
Consultant in charge of patients' care: ensure that the patient under their care has the appropriate care that is expected for patient that has an AKI.
Junior Medical Staff:
Ensure that appropriate pathways are executed
Ensure clear documentation in the notes, including the minimum entry for quality improvement processes.
AKI Specialist Nurse
Review in-hospital AKI stage 2 and 3 for active management
Educate healthcare professionals in the trust about the AKI policy
Monitor parameters in the trust that impact on AKI outcomes
Working with other groups to improve hospital outcomes
Liaising with the renal team
Experienced Nurses or Allied Health Professionals:
Key Elements of Policy / Guideline
NHS England AKI Algorithm

6.1.1  The Trust laboratory information management system is compliant with the Patient Safety Alert on the use of NHS England Acute Kidney Injury Detection Algorithm since 2014. This algorithm alerts clinicians on the possibility of AKI in their patients. This algorithm compares serum creatinine against available lowest serum creatinine

results within the last 7 days. If this is not available, it compares against the median serum creatinine in the last one year. In the absence of serum creatinine results in the past year, the algorithm then compares the serum creatinine with the appropriate age and sex based population interval. Clinicians will still have to use their diagnostic discretion in confirming the diagnosis and stage of AKI.
Causes of Acute Kidney Injury

6.2.1  The commonest precipitating events in hospital are sepsis and hypo-perfusion. The overall acute kidney injury is usually due to multiple factors and each factor has to be considered using the STOP acronym.

table_items.text: Pneumonia  Decreased intake Urosepsis  Increased fluid loss Peritonitis  Heart failure Hypovolaemia / Shock  Chronic Liver Disease
Intravenous contrast  NSAIDS Gentamicin  ACE inhibitors, ARB Penicillin  Herbal
Bladder outflow obstruction Pelvic Tumour Kidney stone
Glomerulonephritis (with systemic vasculitis or lupus) Myeloma Haemolytic-Uraemia Syndrome

data.text: Table1. Causes of AKI
Assessment and Management of Acute Kidney Injury
6.3.1 Sepsis and Hypo-perfusion
6.3.2 The major categories of AKI in hospital are sepsis and hypo-perfusion. Treatment of the underlying process is the main goal.
6.3.3 Sepsis
The sepsis seven care bundles should be initiated as early as possible. Multiple mechanisms, including hypo-perfusion, contribute to AKI in septicaemia.
Symptoms and potential source of infection: fever, cough, dysuria, diarrhoea, ulcers etc.
Use the “quick SEPSIS RELATED ORGAN FAILURE ASSESSMENT (qSOFA)” if sepsis is suspected: altered mental state (GCS ≤ 15); fast respiratory state (RR ≥ 22), low blood pressure (SBP ≤ 100mmHg)
Anti-biotic treatment should follow trust antibiotic guideline policy.
Caution should be used with gentamicin dosing in the setting of AKI with Urosepsis, one off dosing of 1-2mg/kg with subsequent dosing determined by levels daily is ideal.
6.3.4 Hypo-perfusion
Conduct ABCDE assessment, including full set of observations, fluid status assessment, and EWS score.
Fluid intake and loss should be ascertained. Review available information (fluid charts and urine output). Commence strict input and output charts.
Patients that are predisposed to decreased intake are patients who are made nil by mouth, may not be able to drink by themselves or have a decreased thirst drive.
Increased losses may occur in patients with a history of a diarrhoeal illness or output from fistula or a stoma.
JVP, heart rate, blood pressure, capillary refill / peripheral perfusion
Look for signs of shock i.e. SBP <90mmHg and/or low GCS. If the patient is well, a lying and standing may unmask volume depletion
Monitoring if urine output is ideal but catherisation should be avoided if possible if it can be done by the patient themselves with the use of a fluid chart.
Daily weights are the best assessment of overall fluid status of the patient in hospital.
Prescribe fluids (oral or intra-venous)
Target blood pressure should be set and use of inotropes / vasopressors should be considered early if hypotension is not responding to fluid resuscitation.

Patients with severe heart failure, chronic liver disease and nephrotic syndrome have a low effective circulating volume and are a difficult group of patients to manage. Specialist advice should be sought (nephrology, cardiology, gastroenterology, high-dependency/intensive care).
Renal artery stenosis can cause an AKI in a setting of systemic hypo- perfusion or if angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptors blockers are started.
Toxin / Drugs
A detailed drug history should be obtained to consider potential causes or contributory medications of AKI.
Ask about drugs bought over the counter such as non-prescription pain killers or herbal medications (ordered over the internet as food supplements, Chinese, Indian Ayurveda).
Common direct kidney toxins that should ideally be avoided or their use minimised in “at risk” patients (see below) are:
Some drugs may contribute to AKI in certain circumstances;
Drug that are eliminated (or cleared) by the kidneys that may become toxic by accumulation in AKI.
Metformin should usually be stopped as it can exacerbate acidosis
Insulin may need to be reduced as it may precipitate hypoglycaemia (Insulin is excreted by the kidneys). T1DM should never have insulin stopped completely.

Rarely, a specific drug can cause an “allergic reaction in the kidney” and this may coincide with the initiation of a new drug or a known previously allergy to a drug such as penicillin or vancomycin. A raised eosinophil count of the full blood count is suggestive of this.

Certain chemotherapy agents and specialist anti-biotic / antifungals / anti-viral can cause AKI. A more detailed summary of drugs in relation to AKI is provided by the think kidneys campaign. Specific advice can be given by the members of the pharmacy team and there is Think Kidneys guidance associated with these trust guidelines.
Obstruction

Benign prostatic hyperplasia is an easily treatable cause of obstruction that still remains a cause of acute and chronic kidney injury. A history of “prostatism” (or voiding symptoms) such as difficulty initiation of micturition, poor stream or terminal dribbling should point to a bladder outflow obstruction.
Older women can get bladder outflow obstruction due to cervical insufficiency, especially if there is a history of multiple vaginal deliveries, and input from gynaecology is required to manage this.

Constipation is a common cause of bladder outflow obstruction in older, frail people who may be bed-bound. A volume of 350mls post micturition may suggest underlying obstruction and urinary catheter should be considered to relieve obstruction.

Patients with a history of renal stones or presenting with renal colic should always be considered for urgent management with intravenous fluid administration and an urgent ultrasound (<24 hours). If concurrent infection, i.e. pyonephrosis, is suspected, ultrasound should be done immediately if decompression is planned (even out of hours).

Patients with a pelvic malignancy or pelvic disease in metastatic cancer are at risk of obstruction, and an urgent (<24 hours) ultrasound should be obtained in these patients with input from the relevant oncology team.
Primary Kidney Disease

This is an infrequent cause of AKI but early recognition is important as potential lifesaving or kidney saving treatment needs to be instituted early. It is beyond the scope of this guidance to go into details of condition this group encompasses by a brief overview is given to facilitate early discussion with the relevant specialty.

Look for potential systemic disease such as a vasculitis (haemoptysis, rash, uveitis, arthritis). Patient may have a history of an auto-immune condition. Patients can be generally well will no sign of any other cause.

Suspect AKI due to primary kidney disease if urine dip has significant quantities of blood and protein. Perform Acute Renal Screen: ANA, ANCA, Anti-GBM, Complements and Cryoglobulins, Creatine Kinase, LDH and peripheral blood film (if HUS/TTP suspected), serum protein electrophoresis, serum free light chains and urine for Bence Jones protein.

Multiple myeloma is a common cause in the older person and can be missed if not specifically looked for. This can occur in older people if there is no other obvious cause, there may be concurrent abnormal full blood count (anaemia), hypercalcaemia or raised serum total protein.
Summary of Investigations and management in AKI

table_items.text: Urine MC+S Stool MC+S Sputum MC+S Blood culture ECG Echocardiogram Chest X ray
Stop all toxins and potential drugs that may compound further injury to kidney. Modify doses of prescribed medications if required.
Disease specific treatment such as immunosuppression, chemotherapy or plasma exchange. (involve specialist teams)

data.text: Table 2 Management of AKI
Complications of AKI

6.8.1 The main complications that have to be managed with an AKI are hyperkalaemia, acidosis, volume overload, and uraemia. The mainstay of treatment should be the treatment of the underlying cause. Severe manifestations of complications should warrant consideration of renal replacement and discussion with the renal team or intensive care unit.
6.8.2 Hyperkalaemia
Refer to Hyperkalaemia guidelines
6.8.3 Acidosis
Acidosis needs to be treated by renal replacement; isotonic (1.26%, or 1.4%) sodium bicarbonate can be used with senior advice to help manage hyperkalaemia.
6.8.4 Uraemia

Uraemic encephalopathy or pericarditis are rare but is an indication for renal replacement. Uraemic encephalopathy can manifest as an acute confusion and the patient may have an Asterixis. A pericardial rub may be present in pericarditis.
6.8.5 Volume overload
The danger is precipitating fluid overload which has been shown to cause worse outcomes in patients with AKI.
The only way of fluid removal in a patient with oliguria renal failure is by using renal replacement such as Hemofiltration or dialysis.
6.8.6 Pulmonary Oedema
Sit the patient up and give oxygen  L/min through non-rebreathe mask, and then titrate according to ABG results.
If haemodynamic ally stable give furosemide 80mg IV
If haemodynamic ally stable commence GTN 1-10mg/hour titrating dose.
High risk population

6.9.1 Certain groups of patients are at risk of AKI and consideration should be given to prevent an AKI in the first instance or institute management as early as possible (i.e. before blood results are available).
6.9.2 These  patients  should  be  counselled  for  sick  day  rules  where  ACEI/ARB  and diuretics should be withheld temporarily during periods of inter-current illness.

table_items.text: Patient specific – Susceptibility Older age  Past history of AKI Hypovolaemia, dehydration, reduced  Neurological or cognitive oral intake impairment or disability, which may Hypotension mean limited access to fluids Sepsis because of reliance on a carer CKD (eGFR <60)  Symptoms or history of urinary tract Diabetes mellitus obstruction, or conditions that may Heart failure lead to obstruction Liver disease  Immunosuppressed or deficient immunity e.g. malnutrition, patients with cancer

Situation specific – Susceptibility Post-operative Use of iodinated contrast agents within the past week Use of drugs such as non-steroidal anti- inflammatory drugs [NSAIDs], angiotensin- converting enzyme [ACE] inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor antagonists [ARBs] and diuretics) within the past week, especially if hypovolaemic Poor access to fluids i.e. bed bound

data.text: Table 3. High risk population for AKI
General guidance to minimise AKI with intravenous contrast administration

6.10.1 Contrast induced AKI may have been previously overestimated as many patients who develop AKI post contrast exposure in an acute setting have a scan in a setting of an acute illness which could cause AKI. The term contrast associated AKI is now being used to as replacement to highlight this point.

6.10.2 The AMACING study data suggests that there is no evidence for routine use of intravenous hydration in patients with eGFR >30 ml/min/1.73m3. The PRESERVE study also did not show any benefit in patients who received sodium bicarbonate or normal saline over placebo. A prior called POSEIDON demonstrated benefit in haemodynamic-guided fluid administration for patients at risk of AKI defined by eGFR <60 ml/min/1.73m3.

6.10.3 A reasonable stance is the the patients with eGFR <  or other factor that make them at risk must be adequately volume replete before exposure. At-risk in-patients (table 3) who are volume deplete or euvolaemic may benefit from intravenous hydration (suggested regime of 1L  hours before and 1L  hours after for in- patients) and withholding diuretics, ACE/ARB, and other nephrotoxic agents. We would not anticipate out-patients to be volumes deplete and oral hydration should be encouraged if there is risk.
Training Requirements
Currently training is undertaken on an ad hoc basis with teaching sessions by AKI Specialist Nurse and renal doctors.
Monitoring and Audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Numbers of AKI stage 1, 2 and 3 from biochemistry
Deterioration of AKI stage 1 and 2 to 2 and 3, respectively
Mortality and length of stay for AKIs

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the renal consultants in conjunction with the AKI clinical specialist nurses across the MSE group of hospitals. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE renal consultants and the AKI nurses of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Quality Impact Assessment

table_items.text: What evidence has been used to develop this proposal e.g. NICE, NCEPOD, audit, patient or staff surveys?
What changes does this proposal make to the care pathway?
Pathway to be enacted more robustly
Describe the positive impact on: Patient safety Clinical effectiveness Patient experience
This will ensure that pathway is applied to all patients, thereby, ensuring minimum standard of care for patients with AKI.
What current or new clinical outcome measures will monitor these benefits?
As per monitoring and audit in section 7

Describe how the impact of the change has been considered in relation to: Infection Prevention and Control Safeguarding vulnerable adults/ children Current quality indicators Quality Account priorities Patients/ carers/ members of the public Promoting self-care for people with long-term conditions Tackling health inequalities

Acute renal failure mortality is shown in the SHMI data which is open to public and where the hospital is held accountable. Ensuring standard care is applied with tackle inequalities at different times of the day / week.
How will you monitor the impact of this proposal? Provide details of how this will be done, by whom, and when.
These are described in the audit and monitoring section
Worsening rate of deterioration of AKI

Management of hyperkalaemia to be in line with national guidance

National Patient Safety Alert for AKI and NICE guidelines on AKI
Who benefits from this change and how?
Patients who have this common medical complication will have clear consistent treatment in line with national guidance
